item.title: Ukraine’s Forces Push Forward on Two Fronts
item.description: Russian-installed officials acknowledged losing ground in both the east and south, as Ukraine’s troops sought to extend a run of battlefield successes.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign fighters near the town of Lyman, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia’s Annexation Claim Is News to Residents of Lyman, Ukraine
item.description: Without access to electricity, radios or the internet, residents of Lyman said they were unaware of President Vladimir V. Putin’s grandiose celebration of an illegal land grab.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A badly damaged building in Lyman, a strategic rail hub.

item.title: Truss, in Reversal, Drops Plan to Cut U.K. Tax Rate on High Earners
item.description: The announcement was a major capitulation by the government after the tax cuts it announced roiled financial markets and drew widespread criticism.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain, center, has been forced to change course during her Conservative Party’s showpiece annual conference in Birmingham, England.

item.title: Bolsonaro Outperforms Polls and Forces Runoff Against Lula in Brazil’s Presidential Election
item.description: The two political titans will face off again later this month in a race widely seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

item.title: Authorities Will Work to Identify Suspects in Stampede Within Days
item.description: An investigation will focus on police officers suspected of using tear gas to disperse fans in the overcrowded stadium. At least 125 people died, many trampled, after Saturday’s game.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Arema Football Club mourning the victims of the stampede outside Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, East Java, on Monday.

item.title: Arema fans gather for a weeklong vigil to pay respects to the dead.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Arema fans gathering for a vigil in Malang, Indonesia, on Sunday.

item.title: The Kremlin, after trumpeting annexation, admits it doesn’t know where the borders are.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian running on a destroyed bridge over the Oskil River, in Kupiansk, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: In Quebec, the Independence Movement Gives Way to a New Nationalism
item.description: In Monday’s election, residents of a town that was once a stronghold of the independence movement are expected to back the province’s popular premier, who has embraced a nationalism based on French Québécois identity.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign that reads, “Yes, keeping the flame alive” in French adorned a house in L’Assomption, Quebec.

item.title: In Burkina Faso, the Man Who Once Led a Coup Is Ousted by One
item.description: Lt. Col. Paul-Henri Sandaogo Damiba seized power in a coup in January. But factions of the military grew frustrated with his handling of a security crisis plaguing the West African nation.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Capt. Ibrahim Traoré, Burkina Faso’s new self-declared leader, on Sunday in Ouagadougou, the capital.

item.title: Maggie Haberman Talks About Reporting on Donald Trump
item.description: He often utters falsehoods, but his speaking style is more strategic than it sometimes seems. Listen for the first time to audio clips from interviews with Maggie Haberman.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump in Warren, Mich., this weekend.

item.title: Ukraine’s First Lady Tells ’60 Minutes’ of the War’s Impact
item.description: Olena Zelenska told CBS News that Russian attacks on schools, hospitals and residential areas have been a form of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Juston Jones
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena Zelenska, the Ukrainian first lady, at a session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York last month.

item.title: Unearthing Everyday Life at an Ancient Site in Greece
item.description: Excavations in the Peloponnesian village of Iklaina are yielding rich insights into the lives of the Mycenaean civilization’s general population.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stirn
item.media:description: An archaeologist carefully unearths a pottery fragment.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine Is Awarded to Svante Pääbo
item.description: The Swedish geneticist was honored for his work in sequencing the genome of the Neanderthal, an extinct relative of present-day humans.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller

item.title: Indonesian human rights official says tear gas likely played a key role in the disaster.
item.description: An initial examination shows that police also used violent force against fans. Without gas, the tragedy might have been avoided, the organization said.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Police inside the Kanjuruhan Stadium on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Nord Stream leakages stop.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Danish Defence Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images

item.title: The investigation will take two weeks, an official says.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Police officers trying to stop fans from entering the field during a clash between fans at Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, Indonesia, on Sunday.

item.title: Nord Stream Pipelines Have Stopped Leaking After Earlier Damage
item.description: Both European and Russian leaders have said that ruptures discovered undersea were an act of sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Danish Defense Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gas leaks were discovered on Nord Stream pipelines in the Baltic Sea last week.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Hunt Demoralized Russian Stragglers in Lyman
item.description: A major Russian newspaper said the Russian troops, facing defeat in Lyman, had fled with “empty eyes” after barely escaping with their lives.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank near a recaptured area north of Lyman in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Indonesia’s Stadium Tragedy
item.description: Plus Brazil votes in national elections and China wrestles with Covid fatigue.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Soccer fans carrying an injured man away from the stadium.

item.title: If Bolsonaro disputes a loss, some supporters are ready to take to the streets.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, Flávia Milhorance, Laís Martins and Leonardo Coelho
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, top, speaking to supporters in São Paulo, Brazil, last month.

item.title: Nine NATO nations express support for Ukraine’s membership bid.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, in Brussels, Belgium, on Friday.

item.title: Putin’s Claims to Donetsk Are News To Some Residents of Newly-Liberated Lyman
item.description: Russia’s president decreed on Friday that four regions of Ukraine including Donetsk, where Lyman is located, would be absorbed into Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed building in Lyman, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Hurricane Orlene Makes Landfall in Western Mexico
item.description: Orlene, a Category 1 storm, could deliver as much as 14 inches of rain to some areas, forecasters said. The system was expected to weaken, but Mexican authorities cautioned about potential flooding.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: A satellite image of Hurricane Orlene on Monday. The storm could bring flash flooding and landslides across southwest Mexico through Tuesday, forecasters said.

item.title: A soldier and civilian are treated side-by-side at a field hospital in the south.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung

item.title: Indonesian Soccer Stadium Deaths Prompt Focus on Police
item.description: Witnesses said officers fired tear gas indiscriminately into the stands, causing a stampede that led to at least 125 deaths.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Police officers firing tear gas into crowds at Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, Indonesia, on Saturday.

item.title: Chinese #MeToo Case Settled in U.S. Court
item.description: The case, involving a billionaire entrepreneur, riveted observers in China, where women alleging sexual wrongdoing by powerful men are often pilloried, silenced or both.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Chang Che
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Jingyao filed a civil suit accusing the Chinese tech billionaire Richard Liu of raping her in Minneapolis in 2018.

item.title: Deaths Are Rare at Soccer Games, but Aggressive Policing Can Light a Match
item.description: This is not the first time this year that the sport has had to confront the reality that tragedies often result from failures of policing, security and crowd management.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: An officer spraying tear gas at Liverpool fans before the Champions League final in France in May.

item.title: Families Share Stories of Death and Survival After Indonesian Stadium Disaster
item.description: Dozens of people sat on mats with bags of fruit and bottles of water waiting for their relatives’ name to be called.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Relatives of victims waited outside a hospital in Malang, East Java, on Sunday after the deadly episode at the soccer stadium there.

item.title: How the U.K. Finance Minister Came to Ignore Finance Experts
item.description: Kwasi Kwarteng, the chancellor of the Exchequer, faces widespread anger over the tax cuts he and Liz Truss have pushed, but their history of dismissing the economic establishment goes back years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a series of tax cuts that sent the markets spiraling.

item.title: A choice between two heavyweights
item.description: Brazil votes for president today. Jack Nicas, the bureau chief there, explains what’s at stake.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: From left: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times; Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenger, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, left, and the incumbent, President Jair Bolsonaro. Mr. da Silva leads in the polls.

item.title: Bolsonaro outperforms the polls as Brazil’s election appears headed to a runoff.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: From left: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times; Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenger, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, left, and the incumbent, President Jair Bolsonaro. Mr. da Silva leads in the polls.

item.title: Leicester Tensions Have Roots in India
item.description: Violent confrontations in Leicester have prompted soul searching in an area long heralded as a success story of diversity and integration among its large Indian diaspora.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A predominantly Muslim area of Leicester, England. Experts say the tangles between mostly Hindu and Muslim men last month were only the latest examples of how toxic politics in India have migrated overseas.

item.title: Indonesian Fan Still Hears ‘Voices Screaming’ After Match
item.description: One witness said most of the victims were people trapped in the stands, not those on the field. Without tear gas “there would have not been any casualties,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: At the Kanjuruhan Stadium on Sunday.

item.title: Putin’s nuclear threats stir growing alarm in Washington.
item.description: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia displayed on Friday on a screen in Moscow as he addressed the sham annexation of four regions of Ukraine.

item.title: Indonesian Soccer Tragedy Is Latest in History of Stadium Disasters
item.description: These events have prompted major changes. But fatal tramplings still occur, with more than 125 killed in Indonesia on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: People fleeing tear gas at the Estadio Nacional in Lima on May 24, 1964.

item.title: Iran Protests Fueled by Sickly Economy
item.description: The country’s long economic decline has been one of the main forces sending Iranians into the streets over the past two weeks to demand change.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shopping at the Tajrish Bazaar in Tehran in June. Prices for some goods in Iran are up as much as 75 percent from last year.

item.title: Zelensky says Russia’s retreat shows its annexation moves are a ‘farce.’
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service of President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday in Kyiv.

item.title: Ukraine Forces Retake Lyman, a Strategic City, as Russians Retreat
item.description: Russia’s withdrawal from the city comes one day after Moscow illegally annexed the surrounding region.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Bakhmut on Saturday.

item.title: Gazprom halts gas supplies to Italy.
item.description: The Italian gas provider Eni said that the Russian monopoly did not deliver the natural gas it had booked for Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: The headquarters of Eni in Rome, Italy, in 2017.

item.title: Putin Supporters Enraged By Russian Retreat From Lyman
item.description: The criticism of the Kremlin after Russia retreated from the key rail hub on Saturday came not just from pro-war commentators on social media, but from two senior allies of Mr. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Ramzan Kadyrov in Chechnya’s regional capital of Grozny, Russia, in March.

item.title: A Russian military plane catches fire at a Crimean air base, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

item.title: In Washington, Putin’s Nuclear Threats Stir Growing Alarm
item.description: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia displayed on Friday on a screen in Moscow as he addressed the sham annexation of four regions of Ukraine.

item.title: Uganda Races to Contain a Deadly Ebola Outbreak
item.description: The outbreak was caused by the Sudan strain of the virus, which has no approved vaccine or drug treatment. Scientists are now rushing to begin clinical trials in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Members of the Ebola treatment unit this past week at Mubende Regional Referral Hospital in Uganda.

item.title: Here’s why Russia’s retreat from Lyman matters.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military truck near Lyman, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: ‘Naked Fear’: A Pipeline Attack Fans Anxiety in a German Village, and Beyond
item.description: The act of sabotage has brought the Ukraine war closer, raising anxiety levels and threatening to undermine the Europeans’ resolve to help Ukraine fight on.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany, on Friday.

item.title: Backing Lindt, Swiss Court Orders Lidl to ‘Destroy’ Its Chocolate Bunnies
item.description: With Easter still far away, there are none to melt down. But the decision opened a door on the bunny-eat-bunny world of European chocolatiers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Lindt, the Swiss chocolate maker, is protective of its “Gold Bunny.”

item.title: Broken glass, blown-out tires and a crater show the violence of a deadly attack in Zaporizhzhia.
item.description: The strike hit a convoy of people fleeing fighting, killing at least 30.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen walking by a crater left by a missile strike near Zaporizhzhia on Friday.

item.title: New Burkina Faso Coup Raises Question About Security
item.description: Unrest quickly escalated in Burkina Faso’s capital, Ouagadougou, as military officers who removed another military leader accused France of helping him stage a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Soldiers standing guard in an armored vehicle in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Saturday.

item.title: Making Friends
item.description: A psychologist and friendship expert has advice for how to make friends as an adult.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Alberta Revives Its Long-Running Campaign Against Federal Gun Controls
item.description: Alberta, later followed by Saskatchewan, has directed Mounties in the province not to participate in a buyback program for banned rifles.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Alberta has instructed Mounties within its border to not buy back banned rifles.

item.title: Battered by Floods and Trapped in Debt, Pakistani Farmers Struggle to Survive
item.description: The recent flooding has plunged small farmers in sharecropping arrangements further into debt with their landlords — a cycle that has worsened as extreme weather events become increasingly common.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Brazil Faces Big Vote in Presidential Election: Bolsonaro vs. Lula.
item.description: Brazilians voting for president on Sunday will choose between two political titans in a contest seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: From left: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times; Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenger, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, left, and the incumbent, President Jair Bolsonaro. Mr. da Silva leads in the polls.

item.title: In China, Living Not ‘With Covid,’ but With ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: The country’s strict coronavirus restrictions dictate the patterns of daily life, like waiting in line for frequent Covid tests and stocking up on extra groceries in case of lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A Covid testing station in Beijing in September. The government ordered testing sites to be within a 15-minute walk in cities.

item.title: The U.N. nuclear agency calls for the release of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant’s director general.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in August. The plant was taken by Russian forces in March but is run by Ukrainian engineers.

item.title: Panic, Bribes, Ditched Cars and a Dash on Foot: Portraits of Flight From Russia
item.description: A mountain pass into Georgia has become a choke point for Russians fleeing the country, many of them men who faced being drafted and sent to fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ksenia Ivanova and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Ksenia Ivanova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei with his two children Daniil, 10, and Karina, 10, in a hotel room in Stepatsminda, Georgia.

item.title: North Korea Launches Two Ballistic Missiles, Fourth Test in a Week
item.description: The test came a day after the United States, Japan and South Korea conducted their first joint anti-submarine exercise in five years.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Commuters in a train station on Seoul on Friday pass a screen airing news about a recent North Korean ballistic missile launch.
